entry.title: Project Report
entry.summary:
In this notebook, we summarize our findings. Our main conclusions are:

  • There is a relationship between wheat and inflation. During periods of inflation, wheat prices will be volatile.
  • Current market dictates that both Gold and Silver are affected by periods of inflation and are thus not good hedges against inflation.
In [2]: 
from IPython.display import Image

Team members responsible for this notebook:

  • Alexander Badrenkov: Everything
  • Ivan Kgo: Everything
  • Tony Lin: Everything
  • Yvonne Ng: Everything

The Problem¶

Gold as an inflationary hedge has long been the topic of controversy for investors. Many advise that gold be used as a hedge against inflation while others argue that gold prices are too volatile for this purpose. For our project, we wished to test the functionality of gold as an inflationary hedge.

To measure inflation, we used the percent change in the Consumer Price Index (CPI).

A commodity that is an inflationary hedge will have a market price that moves more slowly or not at all in the direction of inflation (i.e. if overall price levels (CPI) rises, a good that is an inflationary hedge will not increase in price). A commodity that is not an inflationary hedge will be highly affected by inflation (i.e. if CPI rises, the price of a commodity that is not an inflationary hedge will rise with it).

To determine how closely gold prices moved with inflation, we also compared the movements in silver and wheat with inflation. Silver is used as a comparison measure as it belongs to the same industry as gold. Wheat is known to be volatile during times of inflation. From historical data over the last 500 years, we calculated the changes in gold, silver, and wheat prices over time. We then plotted the historical changes in gold, silver, and wheat prices against inflation and created summary statistics that measure how closely the prices of each commodity moved with inflation.

Data Sources¶

We obtained the CPI, gold, and silver files from the GlobalFinancialData website. The website is accessible at https://www.globalfinancialdata.com/Databases/databases.html. This website required a memebership to download the files, so we downloaded them and put them into a google drive. One of the difficulties that we encountered while gathering the data was using the bash command curl to gather something from the google drive instead of from a regular website. The CPI, gold, and silver data was gathered annually and the prices were in pounds.

We obtained the wheat data from two different websites. Wheat data from 1278 to 1817 was obtained from the International Institute of Social History at http://www.iisg.nl/hpw/. Wheat data from 1790 to 1950 was obtained from "Commodity Price Volatility and World Market Integration since 1700," which is accessible at http://www.sfu.ca/~djacks/data/publications/. The wheat data came in excel files with the prices in shillings per quarter gathered annually, seasonally, or monthly (depending on the file). The difficulty that we had with the wheat data was that the the data from "Commodity Price Volatility and World Market Integration since 1700" had data for many commodities that we did not need. We had to take subsets of this data in order to isolate the data that we needed.

All of our data will pertain to the UK.

Main Challenges¶

While working on this project, we encountered numerous challenges. The first challenge that we faced was working outside of Oski Box. Many packages would not load for us (rJava, xlsx). We had to find other ways to load these packages so they would work on our ipython notebook. We sometimes had to use other packages that had the same functionality in order to get something done. We also encountered numerous errors on Oski box. The most prevalent was that the Internet would disconnect on Oski Box while we still had Internet on our computers.

The second challenge that we encountered was gathering the data for such a long period of time and making sure the data came from a specific region of the world. We wanted to gather data over the last 500 years from England. The wheat data was incomplete for a lot of the years. We were forced to combine data from many files together. Even after we did that, we could only have complete data starting from 1550. Luckily, the data for the silver, inflation, and gold was complete and we did not need to go through many files to obtain it.

The last challenge that we faced was analyzing the data. Given the scatterplot of our data, we did not know enough about time series to generate many relevant plots and generate a good explanation of those plots. We did our best to research the effects of economic policies on the prices of gold. Also, we had trouble showing that something was indeed an inflationary hedge. We had to take subsets of the data in order to do so.

Findings¶

We found that gold was indeed an inflationary hedge from the earliest time we had data available until the 1900's. When changes in inflation were positive, gold showed little to no movement in price. This is consistent with the definition of an inflationary hedge.

Graph of price changes of gold vs changes in positive inflation¶

In [3]: 
Image("../visualizations/Gold_Positive_Price_Changes.png")
Out[3]:

The above graph split at the year 1900¶

In [6]: 
Image("../visualizations/Positive_Gold_Clusters.png")
Out[6]:

A possible explanation for the sudden volatility is that during the 1900's, there were multiple policy changes and historical events that got rid of the gold standard. During WWII and the Great Depression, banks slowly changed from being on the gold standard to getting rid of their gold holdings.

Much like with Gold, we expected to see similar results from Silver as they are both from the metal industry and are likely to behave the same way.

Graph of price changes of silver vs changes in positive inflation¶

In [9]: 
Image("../visualizations/Silver_Positive_Price_Changes.png")
Out[9]:

The above graph split at the year 1900¶

In [11]: 
Image("../visualizations/Positive_Silver_Clusters.png")
Out[11]:

From the wheat data that we obtained, we saw that changes in inflation affects changes in the price of wheat. This is coherent with what we believed would happen. Even if we clustered the data (one cluster from 1550-1900 and another 1900-1950), we saw the effect of inflation on wheat prices. We reaffirm that wheat is greatly volatile (as is true with all non-durable goods). It is affected greatly by natural events (like droughts), and by inflation.

Graph of price changes of wheat vs changes in inflation¶

In [8]: 
Image("../visualizations/Wheat_Positive_Price_Changes.png")
Out[8]:

The above graph split at the year 1900¶

In [7]: 
Image("../visualizations/Positive_Wheat_Clusters.png")
Out[7]:

entry.title: Data Analysis
entry.summary:
##Summary

In this notebook, we analyzed our data through the methods of clustering and graphical representation. Our analysis mainly derives from graphical interpretation. We find that Gold and Silver have in the past been stable during times of inflation, but over the past century, volatility has been increasing. Wheat prices have always been volatile. To go straight to our analysis of the graphs, click here.

Team members responsible for this notebook:

List the team members contributing to this notebook, along with their responsabilities:

  • Alexander Badrenkov: Everything
  • Ivan Kho: Everything
  • Tony Lin: Everything
  • Yvonne Ng: Everything
In [2]: 
%load_ext rmagic

Loading Files¶

In [3]: 
%%R
DFGC <- read.csv("../data/cleaned/DF_Gold_Change.csv")
DFSI <- read.csv("../data/cleaned/DF_Silver_Inflation.csv")
DFWC <- read.csv("../data/cleaned/DF_Wheat_change.csv")
positive_gold_inflation_df = read.csv("../data/cleaned/DFG_positive_inflation.csv")
positive_silver_inflation_df = read.csv("../data/cleaned/DFS_positive_inflation.csv")
positive_wheat_inflation_df = read.csv("../data/cleaned/DFW_positive_inflation.csv")
GC_cluster1 = read.csv("../data/cleaned/GC_cluster1.csv")
SI_cluster1 = read.csv("../data/cleaned/SI_cluster1.csv")
wheat_cluster1 = read.csv("../data/cleaned/wheat_cluster1.csv")
GC_cluster2 = read.csv("../data/cleaned/GC_cluster2.csv")
SI_cluster2 = read.csv("../data/cleaned/SI_cluster2.csv")
wheat_cluster2 = read.csv("../data/cleaned/wheat_cluster2.csv")
pos_G_cluster1 = read.csv("../data/cleaned/gold_positive_inflation_cluster1.csv")
pos_S_cluster1 = read.csv("../data/cleaned/silver_positive_inflation_cluster1.csv")
pos_W_cluster1 = read.csv("../data/cleaned/wheat_positive_inflation_cluster1.csv")
pos_G_cluster2 = read.csv("../data/cleaned/gold_positive_inflation_cluster2.csv")
pos_S_cluster2 = read.csv("../data/cleaned/silver_positive_inflation_cluster2.csv")
pos_W_cluster2 = read.csv("../data/cleaned/wheat_positive_inflation_cluster2.csv")

Analysis and Plots¶

  • In all of the graphs, the changes in CPI (i.e. inflation) are displayed red, and the changes in the price of the good are in blue.
  • All plots are saved to the visualization folder as png files. Code not displayed so as to not inhibit the visual representation in this notebook.

Changes in Gold Price From 1257-2011¶

  • As a first step towards meaningful analysis of the data, we saw that there was a marked difference in the behavior of gold and silver prices between 1257 to 1900 and 1900 to 2011. Whereas the price of gold was relatively stable from 1257 to 1900, the price changes became very volatile in the last century, perhaps even more so than inflation.
In [4]: 
%%R
#plot Gold
plot(DFGC$Date,DFGC$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes")
lines(DFGC$Date,DFGC$Change, col="blue")
lines(DFGC$Date,DFGC$Inflation, col="red")
lines(DFGC$Date,DFGC$Change, col="blue")
title("Gold")
  • In order to prove whether gold is an inflationary hedge, we want to look at the positive values of inflation. Our reasoning for this is that inflation is really only a concern to investors when it is positive--when price levels are rising and the currency and the value of certain goods are depreciating. The graph showing only the positive changes in price demonstrates an even more marked difference between the two periods. The price of gold skyrockets greatly during the 1900s.
In [9]: 
%%R
#plot Gold
plot(positive_gold_inflation_df$Date,positive_gold_inflation_df$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes")
lines(positive_gold_inflation_df$Date,positive_gold_inflation_df$Change, col="blue")
lines(positive_gold_inflation_df$Date,positive_gold_inflation_df$Inflation, col="red")
lines(positive_gold_inflation_df$Date, positive_gold_inflation_df$Change, col="blue")
title("Gold (Positive Price Changes)")

Changes in Silver Price From 1257-2011¶

  • Since gold and silver are similar goods in that they are both considered precious metals, we decided to perform the same analysis on silver as well. As expected, we also found a significant difference between the changes in silver prices prior to 1900 and after 1900. The price changes were very small before 1900, but became very volatile aftewards.
In [5]: 
%%R
#plot Silver
plot(DFSI$Date,DFSI$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes")
lines(DFSI$Date,DFSI$Inflation, col="red")
lines(DFSI$Date,DFSI$Change, col="blue")
title("Silver")
  • The difference is more clear when we plot only the positive changes in silver prices with positive inflation, since that is primarily the concern of investors when it comes to silver's strength as a hedge against inflation.
In [6]: 
%%R
#plot positive silver
plot(positive_silver_inflation_df$Date,positive_silver_inflation_df$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes")
lines(positive_silver_inflation_df$Date,positive_silver_inflation_df$Change, col="blue")
lines(positive_silver_inflation_df$Date,positive_silver_inflation_df$Inflation, col="red")
lines(positive_silver_inflation_df$Date, positive_silver_inflation_df$Change, col="blue")
title("Silver (Positive Price Changes)")

Changes in Wheat Price From 1550-1949¶

  • As a contrast to gold and silver prices, we decided to plot the changes in wheat prices against inflation since wheat is a regular commodity whose prices are usually considered volatile and change with inflation. Our expectation proved to be accurate because wheat prices seem to move with inflation in the following graph, no matter what time period is considered.
In [15]: 
%%R
#plot Wheat
plot(DFWC$Date,DFWC$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes")
lines(DFWC$Date,DFWC$Change, col="blue")
lines(DFWC$Date,DFWC$Inflation, col="red")
title("Wheat")
  • Again, we realized that our focus on finding an inflationary hedge meant that we should look at only the positive price changes and positive inflation. Looking at the positive wheat price changes, it becomes even more apparent that there is probably a relationship between changes in wheat prices and inflation. Wheat is probably not a good inflationary hedge.
In [7]: 
%%R
#plot positive wheat
plot(positive_wheat_inflation_df$Date,positive_wheat_inflation_df$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes")
lines(positive_wheat_inflation_df$Date,positive_wheat_inflation_df$Change, col="blue")
lines(positive_wheat_inflation_df$Date,positive_wheat_inflation_df$Inflation, col="red")
lines(positive_wheat_inflation_df$Date, positive_wheat_inflation_df$Change, col="blue")
title("Wheat (Positive Price Changes)")

Changes in Gold Price from 1257 to 1900 (Cluster 1) vs. Changes in Gold Price from 1901 to 2011 (Cluster 2)¶

  • We decided to generate sectioned plots of the same data on gold price changes and inflation that we had previously. We sectioned the data off from 1257 to 1900 in gold cluster 1, and 1900 to 2011 in gold cluster 2. These are helpful visualizations because they demonstrate the difference in the behavior of gold prices before and after this date. Whereas gold prices remained stable in the first cluster, it moved with inflation in the second cluster.
In [9]: 
%%R -r 50 -w 1000 -h 500
# Side by side line plot
par(mfrow=c(1,2))


#plotting gold clusters
plot(GC_cluster1$Date,GC_cluster1$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes", ylim=c(-0.5,.8))
lines(GC_cluster1$Date,GC_cluster1$Inflation, col="red")
lines(GC_cluster1$Date,GC_cluster1$Change, col="blue")
title("Gold Cluster 1")

plot(GC_cluster2$Date,GC_cluster2$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes", ylim=c(-0.5,.8))
lines(GC_cluster2$Date,GC_cluster2$Inflation, col="red")
lines(GC_cluster2$Date,GC_cluster2$Change, col="blue")
title("Gold Cluster 2")

Changes in Silver Price from 1257 to 1900 (Cluster 1) vs. Changes in Silver Price from 1901 to 2011 (Cluster 2)¶

  • We do the same for the silver clustering as we did for gold. That is, we sectioned off our graph for changes in silver price into the two time periods. The difference in volatility of prices becomes more apparent.
In [23]: 
%%R -r 50 -w 1000 -h 500
# Side by side line plot
par(mfrow=c(1,2))

#plotting silver clusters
plot(SI_cluster1$Date,SI_cluster1$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes", ylim=c(-0.5,.8))
lines(SI_cluster1$Date,SI_cluster1$Inflation, col="red")
lines(SI_cluster1$Date,SI_cluster1$Change, col="blue")
title("Silver Cluster 1")

plot(SI_cluster2$Date,SI_cluster2$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes", ylim=c(-0.5,.8))
lines(SI_cluster2$Date,SI_cluster2$Inflation, col="red")
lines(SI_cluster2$Date,SI_cluster2$Change, col="blue")
title("Silver Cluster 2")

Changes in Wheat Price from 1550 to 1900 (Cluster 1) vs. Changes in Wheat Price from 1901 to 1949 (Cluster 2)¶

  • Unlike both gold and silver price changes, the behavior of wheat prices does not seem very different between cluster 1 and cluster 2, which are sectioned off into the period before 1900 and after 1900. In both periods, the wheat prices moved very closely with inflation.
In [10]: 
%%R -r 50 -w 1000 -h 500
# Side by side line plot
par(mfrow=c(1,2))

#plotting wheat clusters
plot(wheat_cluster1$Date,wheat_cluster1$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes", ylim=c(-1.5,1.5))
lines(wheat_cluster1$Date,wheat_cluster1$Inflation, col="red")
lines(wheat_cluster1$Date,wheat_cluster1$Change, col="blue")
title("Wheat Cluster 1")

plot(wheat_cluster2$Date,wheat_cluster2$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes", ylim=c(-1.5,1.5))
lines(wheat_cluster2$Date,wheat_cluster2$Inflation, col="red")
lines(wheat_cluster2$Date,wheat_cluster2$Change, col="blue")
title("Wheat Cluster 2")

Inflation vs Price for positive inflation values¶

  • Finally, we want to look at the positive values of inflation sectioned into our two periods of before 1900 and after 1900 because the question we are trying to answer is whether or not metals, or rather gold, functions as a hedge against inflation. What this means is that we want to know if gold prices will remain stable, or increase during times of high inflation. By breaking up the graph that we began with into these two time periods, the role of gold as an inflationary hedge becomes clear. It was effective as an inflationary hedge before the 1900s, but did not work as an inflationary hedge in the last century.
In [11]: 
%%R -r 50 -w 1000 -h 500
par(mfrow=c(1,2))

plot(pos_G_cluster1$Date, pos_G_cluster1$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes", ylim=c(-0.8,1))
lines(pos_G_cluster1$Date, pos_G_cluster1$Inflation, col="red")
lines(pos_G_cluster1$Date, pos_G_cluster1$Change, col="blue")
title("Positive Gold Cluster 1")

plot(pos_G_cluster2$Date,pos_G_cluster2$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes", ylim=c(-0.8,1))
lines(pos_G_cluster2$Date,pos_G_cluster2$Inflation, col="red")
lines(pos_G_cluster2$Date,pos_G_cluster2$Change, col="blue")
title("Positive Gold Cluster 2")
  • We see a similar phenomenon happening for the change in silver prices as for the change in gold prices. Before 1900, silver prices did not move much as inflation rose. In the period after 1900, however, it seems to move with inflation far more.
In [13]: 
%%R -r 50 -w 1000 -h 500
par(mfrow=c(1,2))

plot(pos_S_cluster1$Date, pos_S_cluster1$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes", ylim=c(-0.8,1))
lines(pos_S_cluster1$Date, pos_S_cluster1$Inflation, col="red")
lines(pos_S_cluster1$Date, pos_S_cluster1$Change, col="blue")
title("Positive Silver Cluster 1")

plot(pos_S_cluster2$Date,pos_S_cluster2$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes", ylim=c(-0.8,1))
lines(pos_S_cluster2$Date,pos_S_cluster2$Inflation, col="red")
lines(pos_S_cluster2$Date,pos_S_cluster2$Change, col="blue")
title("Positive Silver Cluster 2")
  • These are the sectioned and positive data for changes in wheat prices and inflation. We clearly see that in both periods before 1900 and after 1900, positive wheat price changes had a high correspondence with inflation. Wheat did not make a good inflationary hedge in any period.
In [14]: 
%%R -r 50 -w 1000 -h 500
par(mfrow=c(1,2))

plot(pos_W_cluster1$Date, pos_W_cluster1$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes", ylim=c(-0.8,1))
lines(pos_W_cluster1$Date, pos_W_cluster1$Inflation, col="red")
lines(pos_W_cluster1$Date, pos_W_cluster1$Change, col="blue")
title("Positive Wheat Cluster 1")

plot(pos_W_cluster2$Date,pos_W_cluster2$Inflation, type="n", xlab="Year", ylab="Changes", ylim=c(-0.8,1))
lines(pos_W_cluster2$Date,pos_W_cluster2$Inflation, col="red")
lines(pos_W_cluster2$Date,pos_W_cluster2$Change, col="blue")
title("Positive Wheat Cluster 2")

Summary of Data¶

From 1257 to 2011¶

1. Inflation¶

In [15]: 
%%R
print(summary(DFGC$Inflation))

    Min.  1st Qu.   Median     Mean  3rd Qu.     Max. 
-0.43770 -0.04199  0.01037  0.01489  0.06505  0.77190

2. Changes in Gold Price¶

In [16]: 
%%R
print(summary(DFGC$Change))

    Min.  1st Qu.   Median     Mean  3rd Qu.     Max.     NA's 
-1.00000  0.00000  0.00000  0.01061  0.00000  1.18100        1

3. Changes in Silver Price¶

In [17]: 
%%R
print(summary(DFSI$Change))

     Min.   1st Qu.    Median      Mean   3rd Qu.      Max.      NA's 
-0.584900  0.000000  0.000000  0.003472  0.000000  0.861900         1

4. Changes in Wheat Price¶

In [18]: 
%%R
print(summary(DFWC$Change))

    Min.  1st Qu.   Median     Mean  3rd Qu.     Max. 
-0.73700 -0.11360  0.00000  0.02497  0.12950  0.95810

From 1257 to 1900 (Cluster 1)¶

1. Inflation¶

In [19]: 
%%R
print(summary(GC_cluster1$Inflation))

    Min.  1st Qu.   Median     Mean  3rd Qu.     Max. 
-0.43770 -0.05272  0.00000  0.01052  0.06648  0.77190

2. Changes in Gold Price¶

In [20]: 
%%R
print(summary(GC_cluster1$Change))

     Min.   1st Qu.    Median      Mean   3rd Qu.      Max.      NA's 
-0.227300  0.000000  0.000000  0.002586  0.000000  0.250500         1

3. Changes in Silver Price¶

In [68]: 
%%R
print(summary(SI_cluster1$Change))

     Min.   1st Qu.    Median      Mean   3rd Qu.      Max.      NA's 
-0.200300  0.000000  0.000000  0.001904  0.000000  0.250000         1

4. Changes in Wheat Price¶

In [69]: 
%%R
print(summary(wheat_cluster1$Change))

    Min.  1st Qu.   Median     Mean  3rd Qu.     Max. 
-0.73700 -0.12410  0.00000  0.02176  0.13830  0.82050

From 1901-2011 (Cluster 2)¶

1. Inflation¶

In [15]: 
%%R
print(summary(GC_cluster2$Inflation))

    Min.  1st Qu.   Median     Mean  3rd Qu.     Max. 
0.006926 0.024550 0.039770 0.060010 0.076530 0.250000

2. Changes in Gold Price¶

In [16]: 
%%R
print(summary(GC_cluster2$Change))

      Min.    1st Qu.     Median       Mean    3rd Qu.       Max. 
-1.0000000 -0.0172700  0.0009221  0.0632800  0.1035000  1.1810000

3. Changes in Silver Price¶

In [17]: 
%%R

     Min.   1st Qu.    Median      Mean   3rd Qu.      Max.      NA's 
-0.200300  0.000000  0.000000  0.001042  0.000000  0.250000         1

4. Changes in Wheat Price¶

In [18]: 
%%R
print(summary(wheat_cluster2$Change))

    Min.  1st Qu.   Median     Mean  3rd Qu.     Max. 
-0.73700 -0.09028  0.02939  0.04211  0.19200  0.79700

Final Analysis ¶

  • Gold: The "Positive Gold Cluster 1" graph shows that gold prices were relatively less volatile from 1257 to 1900. Changes in gold prices remained close to 0 even though inflation fluctuated greatly. In comparison, gold prices from 1901 to 2011 seemed to fluctuate much more greatly in this period and sometimes moved with inflation.

  • Silver: The "Positive Silver Cluster 1" graph shows that silver prices were relatively less volatile from 1257 to 1900. Changes in silver prices remained close to 0 even though inflation fluctuated greatly. In comparison, gold prices from 1901 to 2011 seemed to fluctuate much more greatly in this period and sometimes moved with inflation.

  • Wheat: In comparison to both gold and silver, there did not seem to be a difference in the behavior of wheat prices between the two periods. Wheat prices were highly volatile throughout the entire period of measurement. This could mean that wheat is greatly affected by inflation, while gold and silver are not as affected.

We deem that for current time, gold will not serve any function as a hedge.

entry.title: Data Cleaning
entry.summary:
Data Cleaning¶

Summary of Notebook:¶

By data cleaning, we mean that we are taking the raw data sets that we have gathered and manipulating them into a form that we can readily access throughout our analysis. The raw data sets for gold prices and price changes, silver prices and price changes, CPI and inflation based on CPI, and wheat prices are all contained in separate CSV files, and these data sets all span across different dates.

Specifically, we need to make sure that the variables that we are plotting and analyzing together will have dates that correspond with one another. We are also grouping variables into different data frame objects and then converting these back into CSV files that contain the selected groupings of data. These groupings will make it easier to generate meaningful plots and analysis.

List of CSV files generated and their corresponding data groupings:

  • DF_Gold.csv: data on gold prices, CPI, and corresponding dates
  • DF_Gold_Changes.csv: data on gold price changes, inflation, and corresponding dates
  • DF_Silver.csv: contains data on silver prices, CPI, and corresponding dates
  • DF_Silver_Inflation.csv: data on silver price changes, inflation, and corresponding dates
  • DF_Wheat.csv: contains data on wheat prices, CPI, and corresponding dates
  • DF_Wheat_change.csv: data on changes in wheat prices, inflation, and corresponding dates
  • DFG_positive_inflation.csv: data on positive changes in gold price and positive inflation
  • DFS_positive_inflation.csv: data on positive changes in silver price and positive inflation
  • GC_cluster1.csv: data on gold prices, CPI, and dates from 1257 to 1900
  • SI_cluster1.csv: data on silver prices, CPI, and dates from 1257 to 1900
  • wheat_cluster1.csv: data on wheat prices, CPI, and dates from 1257 to 1900
  • GC_cluster2.csv: data on gold prices, CPI, and dates from 1900 to 2011
  • SI_cluster2.csv: data on silver prices, CPI, and dates from 1257 to 2011
  • wheat_cluster2.csv: data on wheat prices, CPI, and dates from 1550 to 2011
  • gold_positive_inflation_cluster1.csv: data on positive gold price changes and inflation from 1257 to 1900
  • silver_positive_inflation_cluster1.csv: data on positive silver price changes and inflation from 1257 to 1900
  • wheat_positive_inflation_cluster1.csv: data on positive wheat price changes and inflation from 1551 to 1900
  • gold_positive_inflation_cluster2.csv: data on positive gold price changes and inflation from 1900 to 2011
  • silver_positive_inflation_cluster2.csv: data on positive silver price changes and inflation from 1900 to 2011
  • wheat_positive_inflation_cluster2.csv: data on positive wheat price changes and inflation from 1900 to 2011

Team members responsible for this notebook:

  • Alexander Badrenkov: Cleaning the Wheat data
  • Ivan Kho: Assist in CPI, Gold, Silver, Wheat cleaning
  • Tony Lin: Assist in CPI, Gold, Silver cleaning
  • Yvonne Ng: Assist in CPI, Gold, Silver cleaning

The Cleaning begins¶

Data Cleaning for the CPI, Gold, and Silver will involve R

In [177]: 
%load_ext rmagic

The rmagic extension is already loaded. To reload it, use:
  %reload_ext rmagic

We want to install the necessary packages if they are currently nonexistent. The package "data.table" is used for the function fread, which we use to read data from our CSV files to create data.table and data.frame objects. The package "xlsx" to read our raw wheat data xls files and to write the cleaned wheat data xls file.

In [178]: 
%%R
if(require(data.table)==FALSE)
    install.packages("data.table")
if(require(xlsx)==FALSE)
    install.packages("xlsx")

Loading required package: xlsx
Loading required package: rJava
Error : .onLoad failed in loadNamespace() for 'rJava', details:
  call: dyn.load(file, DLLpath = DLLpath, ...)
  error: unable to load shared object '/home/oski/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/3.0/rJava/libs/rJava.so':

Here, we load the necessary data files to begin working. To work with our CSV files containing the raw data for gold, silver and CPI, we have to set our working directory to the directory containing the three files. We then create a list of all the CSV file names and use these file names to create a list of data.frame objects containing the data. After we finish, we have to set our working directory back to the notebooks directory.

Finally we take the list that we created and separate the data. The CPI and inflation data are stored in the variable cpi, the gold and gold price changes data are stored in the variable gold, and the silver and silver price changes data are stored in the variable silver.

In [179]: 
%%R
#grab csv files
setwd("..")
a = paste(getwd(), "/data/raw/*.csv", sep="")
b = Sys.glob(a)
c = lapply(b, fread)
setwd("notebooks")

# Separate datafiles
cpi <- c[[1]]
gold <- c[[2]]
silver <- c[[3]]

Gold:¶

For the gold data, we want to separate it into two separate data.frame objects. One will contain the year to year gold prices while the other will contain the changes in gold price over year.

Since the CPI and gold data are of different lengths, we have to merge the two data.frame objects according to their corresponding dates.

In [180]: 
%%R
# Because the datasets are of different lengths
# we want to match available time frames
cpi_gold <- merge(cpi,gold, by="Date")
Date <- cpi_gold$Date
CPI <- cpi_gold$Close.x
Inflation <- cpi_gold$Inflation
Gold <- cpi_gold$Close.y
Change <- cpi_gold$Change

We create a matrix from the vectors Date, CPI, and Gold that now contain the data, CPI, and gold data, making each one a column. We then convert this matrix into a data.frame object that we call DFG.

In [181]: 
%%R
# Conversion from matrix to DataFrame for gold prices
cpi_gold_matrix <- cbind(Date, CPI, Gold)
DFG <- as.data.frame(cpi_gold_matrix)

We print out the class of DFG as well as the first few entries of the DFG to verify that we did the conversion from matrix to data.frame correctly.

In [182]:

The column vectors in the data.frame DFG are currently set as factor. In order to work with the gold prices and gold price changes, we will need them to be in numeric form, so we grab the factors and convert them to numeric. For the date, we convert the data from factor to type Date.

In [184]: 
%%R
# Conversion from factor to numeric
Gold_factor <- DFG$Gold
CPI_factor <- DFG$CPI
Gold_numbers <- as.numeric(levels(Gold_factor)[as.integer(Gold_factor)])
CPI_numbers <- as.numeric(levels(CPI_factor)[as.integer(CPI_factor)])
Date <- levels(DFG$Date)[DFG$Date]
Date <- as.Date(Date, format="%m/%d/%Y")
Date <- year(Date)
DFG$Date <- Date
DFG$Gold <- Gold_numbers
DFG$CPI <- CPI_numbers

We print out the classes of the column vectors in the data.frame DFG again to check if the conversion from factor to numeric was performed correctly. We note that they are now numeric.

When we do our analysis, we will also want to look at the positive values of inflation. Our reasoning for this is that inflation is really only a concern to investors when it is positive--when price levels are rising and the currency and the value of certain goods are depreciating. We use logical indexing to create a new data.frame object called pos_DFGC that only contains the positive inflation data.

**Procedure for wheat data: ** Below is the code that gathers the wheat data from 6 files (located in the raw data folder).
1. Load a file.
1. Grab the data for a certain year in our dictionary.
2. Check if that data is empty. If it is, we start a new list for the data points. If it isn't, we grab the list associated with the year we want.
3. For all the values for that year in our current file, add them to the list.
4. Repeat this for all the data in 5 files.
5. Sum all the values of the wheat per year.
6. Put these values in an array and save it to an excel file.

In [20]: 
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from pandas import DataFrame
import xlwt
from tempfile import TemporaryFile

First File (1278-1536)

In [21]: 
# reading from the first xl file
xl = pd.ExcelFile("../data/raw/Wheat_Prices_1278_1536.xls")
df = xl.parse("Wheat")

#gathering all the data into a dictionary by year
dict1 = {}
df2 = DataFrame(df)['Season']
for i in range(0, len(df2)) :
    x = df.iloc[i]['Season'][:4]
    if x in dict1.keys() :
        ls1 = dict1[x]
    else:
        ls1 = []
    for j in range(2, 15) :
        val = df.iloc[i][j]
        if not np.isnan(val) :
            ls1.append(val)
    dict1[int(x)] = ls1

Second File (1594-1681)

In [22]:

        ls1 = dict1[x]
    else:
        ls1 = []
    for j in range(1, 7) :
        val = df3.iloc[i][j]

            ls1.append(val)
    dict1[int(x)] = ls1

Gathering the Averages per Year

In [26]: 
#gather averages of the data
arr = []
for k in range(280, 680):
    if ((1270+k) in dict1.keys() and len(dict1[1270+k]) != 0) :
        ls2 = dict1[1270+k]
        sum = 0.0
        counter = 0.0
        for l in ls2:
            sum = sum + l
            counter = counter + 1
        arr.append(sum/counter/20.0)
    else:
		arr.append(None)

Writing To a New Excel File

In [27]: 
#write to a excel file
book = xlwt.Workbook()
sheet1 = book.add_sheet('Wheat')
for i,e in enumerate(arr):
    sheet1.write(i,1,e)
for i in range(0, 400):
    sheet1.write(i,0,1550+i)
sheet1.write(0,2,0)
for i in range(1, 400):
    if arr[i] != None and arr[i-1] != None :
        sheet1.write(i,2,(arr[i]-arr[i-1])/arr[i-1])
    else :
        sheet1.write(i,2,0)

name = "Cleaned_Wheat.xls"
book.save("../data/cleaned/"+name)

Write data frames as csv files¶

Cluster data¶

We want to separate the data into 2 clusters (one from the years before 1900, and one after). We do all this by using logical indexing.

In [38]: 
%%R
first_inflation_GC_cluster = DFGC[DFGC$Date < 1901, 2] #2 is Inflation, #3 is change in price
second_inflation_GC_cluster = DFGC[DFGC$Date > 1900, 2]
first_price_GC_cluster = DFGC[DFGC$Date < 1901, 3]
second_price_GC_cluster = DFGC[DFGC$Date > 1900, 3]

first_inflation_SI_cluster = DFSI[DFSI$Date < 1901, 2]
second_inflation_SI_cluster = DFSI[DFSI$Date > 1900, 2]
first_price_SI_cluster = DFSI[DFSI$Date < 1901, 3]
second_price_SI_cluster = DFSI[DFSI$Date > 1900, 3]

first_inflation_wheat_cluster = DFWC[DFWC$Date < 1901, 2] #2 is Inflation, #3 is change in price
second_inflation_wheat_cluster = DFWC[DFWC$Date > 1900, 2]
first_price_wheat_cluster = DFWC[DFWC$Date < 1901, 3]
second_price_wheat_cluster = DFWC[DFWC$Date > 1900, 3]

first_inflation_G_pos_cluster = pos_DFGC[pos_DFGC$Date < 1901, 2] 
second_inflation_G_pos_cluster = pos_DFGC[pos_DFGC$Date > 1900, 2]
first_price_G_pos_cluster = pos_DFGC[pos_DFGC$Date < 1901, 3]
second_price_G_pos_cluster = pos_DFGC[pos_DFGC$Date > 1900, 3]

first_inflation_S_pos_cluster = pos_DFSI[pos_DFSI$Date < 1901, 2] 
second_inflation_S_pos_cluster = pos_DFSI[pos_DFSI$Date > 1900, 2]
first_price_S_pos_cluster = pos_DFSI[pos_DFSI$Date < 1901, 3]
second_price_S_pos_cluster = pos_DFSI[pos_DFSI$Date > 1900, 3]

first_inflation_W_pos_cluster = pos_DFWC[pos_DFWC$Date < 1901, 2] 
second_inflation_W_pos_cluster = pos_DFWC[pos_DFWC$Date > 1900, 2]
first_price_W_pos_cluster = pos_DFWC[pos_DFWC$Date < 1901, 3]
second_price_W_pos_cluster = pos_DFWC[pos_DFWC$Date > 1900, 3]

Next, we turn the data into data frames

In [39]: 
%%R
GC_cluster1 = cbind(DFGC$Date[DFGC$Date < 1901], first_inflation_GC_cluster, first_price_GC_cluster)
GC_cluster1 = as.data.table(GC_cluster1)
GC_cluster1 = as.data.frame(GC_cluster1)
names(GC_cluster1) = c("Date", "Inflation", "Change")

SI_cluster1 = cbind(DFSI$Date[DFSI$Date < 1901], first_inflation_SI_cluster, first_price_SI_cluster)
SI_cluster1 = as.data.table(SI_cluster1)
SI_cluster1 = as.data.frame(SI_cluster1)
names(SI_cluster1) = c("Date", "Inflation", "Change")

wheat_cluster1 = cbind(DFWC$Date[DFWC$Date < 1901], first_inflation_wheat_cluster, first_price_wheat_cluster)
wheat_cluster1 = as.data.frame(wheat_cluster1)
names(wheat_cluster1) = c("Date", "Inflation", "Change")

gold_positive_inflation_cluster1 = cbind(pos_DFGC$Date[pos_DFGC$Date < 1901], first_inflation_G_pos_cluster, first_price_G_pos_cluster)
gold_positive_inflation_cluster1 = as.data.frame(gold_positive_inflation_cluster1)
names(gold_positive_inflation_cluster1) = c("Date", "Inflation", "Change")

wheat_positive_inflation_cluster1 = cbind(pos_DFWC$Date[pos_DFWC$Date < 1901], first_inflation_W_pos_cluster, first_price_W_pos_cluster)

entry.title: Data Gathering
entry.summary:
Data Gathering¶

In this notebook, we gathered data on Gold, Silver, Wheat, and Inflation. The data gathered came in two formats: xlsx and csv. More details about where the data was found and a description of variables used can be found below.

Important!!

If the package xlsx does not run for you, please exit the notebook completely and run the following command in the bash:

R CMD javareconf -e

Then run the notebook once more. This makes it so that the package xlsx will run.

Team members responsible for this notebook:

  • Ivan Kho: Gathering the Cpi, Gold, and Silver data
  • Alexander Badrenkov: Gathering the Wheat data

Creating the directory structure

In [1]: 
%%bash
mkdir ../script ../data ../data/raw ../data/cleaned  ../visualizations
ls -r

Wheat_Segmenting.R
Wheat_Prices_1929_1955.xls
Wheat_Prices_1850_1950_2.xlsx
Wheat_Prices_1850_1950.xlsx
Wheat_Prices_1790_1850_2.xlsx
Wheat_Prices_1790_1850.xlsx
Wheat_Prices_1657_1817.xls
Wheat_Prices_1594_1681.xls
Wheat_Prices_1278_1536.xls
Wheat_Clean.py
UK_silver Prices per oz. (1257-2011).csv
UK_gold Prices (1257-2011).csv
UK_CPI data.csv
R_Wheat.R
README.md
READ.ME.txt
NB4_project_report.ipynb
NB3_data_analysis.ipynb
NB2_data_cleaning.ipynb
NB1_data_gathering.ipynb
Data_Cleaning.R
Cleaned_Wheat.xls

Downloading and displaying raw data¶

In [1]: 
%load_ext rmagic

Getting the Wheat Data¶

These 6 files contain the wheat data that we will use.
These files will be in .xls and .xlsx format.
Data from 1278 to 1817 was obtained from the Internation Insititue of Social History: http://www.iisg.nl/hpw/
Data from 1790 to 1950 was obtained from "Commodity Price Volatility and World Market Integration since 1700" http://www.sfu.ca/~djacks/data/publications/
The prices of the wheat are split up into months or seasons (depending on the file) and are in shillings per quarter.
We used the curl command in bash to grab the excel files and saved them in the raw data folder.

In [2]: 
%%bash
curl http://www.iisg.nl/hpw/varioustowns.xls >> ../data/raw/Wheat_Prices_1278_1536.xls
curl http://www.iisg.nl/hpw/cambridge.xls >> ../data/raw/Wheat_Prices_1594_1681.xls
curl http://www.iisg.nl/hpw/winchester.xls >> ../data/raw/Wheat_Prices_1657_1817.xls
curl http://www.sfu.ca/~djacks/data/publications/Britain,%20Commodity%20Prices,%201790-1850,%20monthly.xlsx >> ../data/raw/Wheat_Prices_1790_1850.xls
curl http://www.sfu.ca/~djacks/data/publications/Britain,%20Commodity%20Prices,%201850-1950,%20annual.xlsx >> ../data/raw/Wheat_Prices_1850_1950.xls
curl http://www.iisg.nl/hpw/englandgrain2.xls >> ../data/raw/Wheat_Prices_1929_1955.xls

Example of the wheat data:
Season refers to the year that the data was gathered.
Michaelmas, Xmas, etc refer to the time of year the data was gathered.

In [3]: 
%%R
library(xlsx)
print(head(read.xlsx("../data/raw/Wheat_Prices_1594_1681.xls", sheetIndex=1)))

     Season Michaelmas   Xmas Candlemas Lady.Day Midsummer Lammas
1 1594-1595     40.000 40.000    40.000   40.000    40.000 40.000
2 1595-1596     40.000 38.333    40.000   27.333    40.000 60.000
3 1596-1597     40.000 42.667    42.667   48.000    58.000 60.000
4 1597-1598     40.000 48.000    50.667   45.333    42.667 42.667
5 1598-1599     29.333 29.333    39.500   28.000    30.667 25.000
6 1599-1600     23.333 24.000    25.000   25.333    40.000 37.333

For the following two files, we only want to grab the wheat data instead of the data for other commodities. We do this by grabbing only certain columns of the excel file, labeling the row/column names, and then saving them to another file in the raw data folder.

In [4]: 
%%R
file <- read.xlsx("../data/raw/Wheat_Prices_1790_1850.xls", 1)
segment <- file[-(1:5),c("NA.","NA..23")]
names(segment) <- c("Year", "Price")
rownames(segment) <- 1:dim(segment)[1]
write.xlsx(segment, "../data/raw/Wheat_Prices_1790_1850_2.xls", sheetName="Wheat")

file2 <- read.xlsx("../data/raw/Wheat_Prices_1850_1950.xls", 1)
segment <- file2[-(1:7),1:2]
names(segment) <- c("Year", "Price")
rownames(segment) <- 1:dim(segment)[1]
write.xlsx(segment, "../data/raw/Wheat_Prices_1850_1950_2.xls", sheetName="Wheat")

NA. refers to the row names.
Year refers to the year the data was gathered.
Price refers to the price of the wheat in shillings per quarter.

In [6]: 
%%R
print(head(read.xlsx("../data/raw/Wheat_Prices_1790_1850_2.xls", sheetIndex = 1)))

  NA. Year Price
1   1 1790    52
2   2 1790  49.5
3   3 1790  49.8
4   4 1790    53
5   5 1790    56
6   6 1790    54

Getting the Gold, Silver, and CPI data¶

The files were gotten from the GlobalFinancialData website here: https://www.globalfinancialdata.com/Databases/databases.html
There are no convienient APIs and you need a membership to grab the data, so they were loaded onto google drive, then downloaded below.
The files contain CPI, gold, and silver information.
The data files were downloaded in .csv format.

The data consists of annual data. The price of Silver and Gold are given in Pounds per Ounce.

In [1]: 
%%bash
curl  https://googledrive.com/host/0B40_9-iPWYmiNUdtNkdTQkoySUU >> "../data/raw/UK_CPI data.csv"
curl  https://googledrive.com/host/0B40_9-iPWYmiZHJjQzI2ZHlnTkE >> "../data/raw/UK_gold Prices (1257-2011).csv"
curl  https://googledrive.com/host/0B40_9-iPWYmidEdzelZ5cVRMamM >> "../data/raw/UK_silver Prices per oz. (1257-2011).csv"

The Date, Close, and Inflation factors are the frames we want to look at.
The Date refers to the date.
The Close refers to the CPI data.
The Inflation refers to the difference between the current and previous year's CPI.

In [18]: 
%%R
print(head(read.csv("../data/raw/UK_gold Prices (1257-2011).csv")))

The Date, Close, and Change are the important columns we want to look at.
The Close references the price of Gold, while the Change refers to the difference between the current and prior year's data.
